June 2023#

1 Thu#

Bash#

A little but of Bash each day keeps the doctors away.

In the main loop, around line 140, we have

read -p "Starting generation ${gen} at location ${state}.\
            Press any key to continue... " -n1 -s

  • option p <prompt> outputs the prompt string before reading user input

  • option n <number> returns after reading the specified number of chars.

  • option s suppresses user input on terminal.

SLURM#

File name replacement:

  1. %x – Job name, which can be given as --job-name=<name>

  2. %a – Job Array ID (index) number

  3. %A – Job Array’s master job allocation number

  4. More options here

Note That the following are not the same:

  • $SLURM_ARRAY_JOB_ID is the %A from above.

  • $SLURM_ARRAY_TASK_ID is the index (%a) from above.

Bash#

A backtick is not a quation mark. For instance:

for i in `seq 1 $NPOP`

Everything we type inside the backticks is executed before the main command (such as chown, and the output of the backticked-command is then read by the main command)

Bash#

  1. The dollar sign works inside the double quotes so there is no need for string concatenation in the example below:

    ~$  a=2;b=2
~$  echo "a * b = $(($a*$b))"

    which returns a * b = 4. Note that the $((...)) part is for Bash arithmetics.

  2. At some point I should try to figure out exactly what double quotes are for in Bash. They seem to be more than just strings?

Python#

XFintoARA.py

  1. Instead of using the %’s for string interpolation, we could use f-strings

  2. Inside the curly braces we can call variables, for instance {g.WorkingDir} `` in ``line 66:

    uanName = f'{g.WorkingDir}/.../{g.gen}_{indiv}_{freqNum}.uan'

  3. The g above is from line 102:

    g = parser.parse_args()

  4. Line 73: mat = [["0" for x in range(n)] for y in range(m)] is simply Python’s way to do mat=zeros(m,n) in Matlab (Python list comprehension).

12 Sun#

Python#

XFintoARA.py

The following pertains line 81 & 82

  1. line 81 first turns the third entry in the list lineList into a float.

  2. line 82 contains the something like "%.2f" % 10**(a) which effectively formats \(10^a\) to two digits after the decimal point. This is not module operation.

  3. The same can be done using an fstring: f'{10**(a):.2f}'

  4. Mostly finished reading this python script. Moving on to part d tomorrow.

General

  1. To access the help message of argpasrse’s add_argument() function, one can run the command

    ~$  python3 <filename.py>.py -h

    in the terminal.

  2. For more information on the argparse module on can look through the documentation and the tutorial

  3. Reviewed file opening (with open, etc)

  4. mode w and w+: the former is write; the latter is read and write.

  5. Apparently with Python3, when using os.chmod one needs to add 0o (/zero-oh/) in front of 777 to grant all read-write-execute permission. For instance:

    os.chmod("filename", 0o777)

    which is the same as chmod 777 filename in Bash.

    This is because

    In unix conventions, written numbers are assumed to be decimal unless they are prefixed with a 0x (or 0X) in which case they are hexadecimal. [2]

    and according to the error message we “use an 0o prefix for octal integers”.

Bash#

  1. Option -e of sed allows for multiple commands at once. For instance,

    sed -e "s/world/universe/" -e "s/hello/goodbye/" ./temp > ./newtemp

    first replaces the word “world” in temp with “universe” and then “hello” with “goodbye” and then pipes these changes to a new file newtemp.

15 Thu#

AraSim Job Submission Script#

  1. Seeds is the number of AraSim jobs of an individual, so num on line 15 is essentially just (ignoring the pesky index issue) `` index`` divided by seeds.

  1. As an example, consider some task 33 in a job array. Suppose Seeds is 8; that is, for each antenna, we do 8 AraSim runs. Since \(33-1=32\) divided by 8 is 4, and then we add one to finally get 5, num in this case is 5. In other words, task 33 is a task for antenna number 5.

  2. Similarly, right below num, seed refers to the “seed index” for that particular antenna. Continuing with the example in item b above, task 33 will be seed number 1 of antenna 5 (start counting from 1, as usual)

  3. Pretty sure line 16

    echo a_${num}_${seed}.txt

    is unnecessary, and the file name being echoed is probably a typo as well?

  4. Line 18 also seems extra? It seems like we are not using this directory anymore?

  5. Line 19 is likely the line that says “run AraSim” (with the appropriate setup and parameters) and then redirecting the output of the run to the (loal) scratch space of the cluster, ie. $TMPDIR. (see OSC documentation on parallel and local scratch space. Basicallly, $TMPDIR is the fastest.

  6. Line 26 is like another SaveState file.

  7. Line 30-33 move the AraSim output files from the scratch space back to the directories under GE60.

Meeting with Julie#

Notes from today’s meeting

  1. HPol – I will probably be using AraSim as is, without having to modify its code.

  2. Dylan built the PUEO software by modifying PAEA. Julie has a to-do list of instructions for him to do it which she will modify and send to me. (edit: link)

  3. Birefringence – Julie said that it sounds like what Amy wants is for HPol to be optimized for birefringence (?), but I don’t need to worry about learning all about birefringence for now, since I will mainly just be working on scripts of the Loop.

  4. Charged current interaction (something like \(\nu + N \to l + X\) where \(nu\) is (anti)neutrino of some flavor \(l\)): The leptons people see are usually muon muons because those are much more stabler than tau (longer lifetime). We don’t see electrons either because they just get reabsorbed immediately into the ice atoms. (Consequently, muons produce tracks whereas the other two create spheres.)

  5. Julie recommends Dick, Chris Hirata, and Antonio Boveia for candidacy.

Bash#

  1. Be sure not to include whitespace when assigning values to variables in Bash. For instance, a = 3 is wrong.

  2. Example usage of expr:

    totPop=$( expr $NPOP \* $Seeds )

    Note the whitespace! it matters here whether or not there are spaces around the multiplication operator.

  3. But what is the difference between expr and simply using double parentheses? For instance totPop=$(( $NPOP * $Seeds ))? Also, in this case it seems like Bash doesn’t care as much about the whitespace around *?

17 Sat#

Meeting with Julie#

Part_D2_Array.sh second pass

  1. Might be able to shortern Line 22:

    nFiles=$(ls -1 --file-type ../AraSimConfirmed | grep -v '/$' | wc -l)

    using just ls | wc -l. Will test this tomorrow.

  2. Option 1 (one) above of ls “[forces] output ot be one entry per line.”

  3. --file-type makes it so that all the directories end with a /, and soft links end with a @, etc. Files don’t have anything attaached to them. [3]

  4. Thus, as an example, inside $WorkingDir/Run_Outputs/2023_02_20_Symmetric_ Run, if we issue ls we get

    2023_02_20_Symmetric_Run.xf  Fitness_Scores_RG.png  uan_files
Antenna_Images               FScorePlot2D.png       Veffectives_RG.png
AraOut                       Gain_Plots             Veff_plot.png
AraSimConfirmed              Generation_Data        Violin_Plot.png
AraSim_Errors                GPUFlags               XF_Errors
AraSimFlags                  Root_Files             XFGPUOutputs
AraSim_Outputs               runDate.txt            XF_Outputs
Evolution_Plots              run_details.txt

    whereas with ls -1 we have

    2023_02_20_Symmetric_Run.xf
Antenna_Images
AraOut
AraSimConfirmed
AraSim_Errors
AraSimFlags
AraSim_Outputs
Evolution_Plots
Fitness_Scores_RG.png
FScorePlot2D.png
Gain_Plots
Generation_Data
GPUFlags
Root_Files
runDate.txt
run_details.txt
uan_files
Veffectives_RG.png
Veff_plot.png
Violin_Plot.png
XF_Errors
XFGPUOutputs
XF_Outputs

    And finally, with ls -1 --file-type (on OSC, not on macOS), we get

    2023_02_20_Symmetric_Run.xf/
Antenna_Images/
AraOut/
AraSimConfirmed/
AraSim_Errors/
AraSimFlags/
AraSim_Outputs/
Evolution_Plots/
Fitness_Scores_RG.png
FScorePlot2D.png
Gain_Plots/
Generation_Data/
GPUFlags/
Root_Files/
runDate.txt
run_details.txt
uan_files/
Veffectives_RG.png
Veff_plot.png
Violin_Plot.png
XF_Errors/
XFGPUOutputs/
XF_Outputs/

  5. option v of grep means “invert-match”, which acts like a not-gate. It selects all entires that do not match. In this case, we are trying to match all entries that has a forward slash / right before the end-of -line character $. That is, we are trying to match all the directories. And then, v makes sure that we select everything that is not a directory, ie. files. Finally, we pipe it to wc -l to count the number of lines as usual to get the number of (ordinary) files.

  6. Will check with Alex to see if we really need to be this careful. In Part_B_GPU_job2_asym_array.sh line 56 it seems like we decided to simply use ls | wc -l, which is much cleaner and readable.

18 Sun#

Meeting with Julie#

Part_D2_Array.sh second pass continued

Regarding the for loop around line 28, consider the following script:

#!/bin/bash
cd ~/Desktop/temp

for file in *
do
    echo $file
done

If there is no file inside temp/, then the output would be *. This is what the comment aounrd line 32 is taling about.

19 Mon#

Bash#

  1. We can break a line inside double quotes. For example, the following is legal

    #!/bin/bash
pat="/users/PAS2137/unmovingcastle/temp"
out_name=$pat/%x.out
err_name=$pat/%x.error
sbatch --job-name=whatever --output=$out_name --error=$err_name a.sh

  2. Normally we don’t even need the backslash if we are just echoing the stuff that is inside the double quotes. But if we are going to access the path later with $pat then it appears that the backslash is necessary.

  3. wait waits for a process to finish. sleep sleeps for a certain number seconds.

Part_E_Asym.sh second pass

    for i in `seq 1 4`
do
    InputFiles="${InputFiles}out${i}.txt "
done
echo $InputFiles

22 Thu#

Meeting with Julie#

Meeting with Julie today moved to tomorrow.

Part_E_Asym.sh second pass continued

  1. Commented out line 109: cd Antenna_Performance_Metric because the next 25 lines have already been commented out so there’s no need.

  2. TODO: look in Data_Generators/gensData_asym.py.

  3. Commented out line 144: cd $WorkingDir/Antenna_Performance_Metric because the subsequent command have already been commented out.

  4. Be very careful with trailing whitespace when using backslash \ to break a line. For example consider line 160

    cd AraOut_${gen}_${i}_${j}.txt \
  $WorkingDir/Run_Outputs/$RunName/AraOut/AraOut_${gen}/AraOut...

    If we add a space after \, notice that the syntax highlighting color changes in VScode and this space will cause a bug, because what this line does is duplicating the source file and then naming the target `` `` (blank); that is, the target file name is simply a whitespace, because the backslash in this case is used to escape the whitespace.

  5. Went through Part_E; looking into the Python and C++ scripts called by this part.

27 Tue#

Meeting with Julie#

Latest_Asym_GA.cpp

  1. Currently on line 340, reviewing <vector>.

  2. Consider the following

    vector<float> fitness (NPOP,0.0f);

    This creates a vector of size NPOP and initializes every entry to be 0.0 (floats).

  3. In Python, fitness = np.zeroes((a,b)) creates a matrix of size a by b and initializes the matrix to zeros.

  4. np.round returns a numpy double but simply round returns and int. We can check this with the type() function (eg. type(round( 59.5)))

  5. TODO: Ask Ryan or Alex why we write to generator.csv.

  6. TODO: Clean up the inner most loop (NVAR) tomorrow. The way the tripple loop is used is sort of ugly.
